message: I usually choose to use an IDE with vi keybindings over vim, mostly because the file management tends to be better in IDEs.  I've done this with Flex Builder (Eclipse), RubyMine, and Netbeans.  I'd rather use vim, but haven't ever gotten used to the file management plugins... who's the same? Can anyone convince me to go pure vim?
check out the plugins "NERDTree" and "Command-T" for file management - they seem to work for me, especially when you get used to command-t
BTW, the only IDE I haven't found vi keybindings for is Xcode, which makes the burn of iPhone coding that much deeper...
In my case it's the switching back & forth to "vim mode" that always makes me give up on IDEs even when they have vim bindings.
the key to making plugins more effective so far for me is to map them to good <leader> shortcuts - ie ,nt for :NerdTreeToggle for me
@ptone, i'll give NERDTree another shot.  and thanks for the shortcut tip, that might be just what i need to take it to the next level!

I've never really found Vim's file managing to be deficient, even when working in a legacy codebase with over ten thousand files.  Between gf (:help gf), tags (:help tags), tag jumping (:he ^] and :he g-^]), file lists (:he quickfix), tag lists (:he :ts) and a few other tools, vim has it pretty covered; no plugins needed.
I have to use Eclipse for work, but viPlugin makes it at least tolerable. http://www.viplugin.com/viplugin/index.php/viplugin/

+1 for nerdtree, although RubyMine and PyCharm (what I use) have the same base platform, so you probably used the same vi plugin (IDEAVim), which I thought was really, really good. What specifically did you find lacking in it?
I think Komodo supports Vim keybindings.
I've heard good things about eclim, but prefer to stick to the NERDtree plugin.
I've been using IdeaVim every day for a year now and it's the best IDE-vim-bindings I've tried so far. (http://plugins.intellij.net/plugin/?id=164)
I tried the Vim plugins for Eclipse, IDEA and NetBeans about 18 months ago. At that time I ordered them from best to worst as NetBeans, IDEA, then Eclipse. That drove me to choose NetBeans as my IDE.
Just an observation, an IDE is much more than a project browser (which is all NERDTree is, really). NERDTree is a great plugin to be sure but an IDE, it isn't.
Wing IDE has vi key bindings (see "Keyboard Personality" in the Edit menu)
